column1: BLOCKCHAIN TECHNOLOGY IN HUMANITARIAN PROGRAMMING A PILOT PROJECT IN CASH TRANSFER PROGRAMMING IN KENYA.pdf
column3: Paper A and Paper B both investigate blockchain applications in humanitarian cash transfer programs but differ in scope and approach, with Paper A presenting a 2018 pilot project in Kenya focusing on technical integration and operational efficiency using an open-loop system combined with mobile money, while Paper B offers a 2022 qualitative socio-technical case study of the large-scale, private permissioned 'Building Blocks' project by WFP, emphasizing governance, power dynamics, and ethical implications beyond technical performance.
column4: Paper A presents an empirical pilot study demonstrating Blockchain’s practical integration with mobile money to enhance transparency and efficiency in humanitarian cash transfers in Kenya, while Paper B offers a systematic scoping review synthesizing emerging literature on Blockchain’s potential for digital identity and health record management in migrant and refugee health, highlighting complementary but distinct applications of Blockchain technology within humanitarian sectors.
column5: Both papers explore Blockchain applications to enhance transparency and accountability in nonprofit sectors—Paper A empirically pilots an open-loop Blockchain cash transfer system integrated with mobile money in humanitarian aid delivery in Kenya, while Paper B qualitatively analyzes an Italian Blockchain-based social marketplace employing dual Blockchains and utility tokens to improve charity fundraising and operations during Covid-19—differing in geographic focus, methodological approach, technological complexity, and sector-specific challenges addressed.
column6: Both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate Blockchain pilot projects within the humanitarian sector but differ in focus—Paper A centers on enhancing transparency and efficiency in cash transfer programming through technological integration in Kenya, while Paper B explores drivers, barriers, and trust-related impacts of Blockchain adoption in humanitarian supply chains in the UK using qualitative multi-method analysis—thereby complementing each other by addressing distinct application domains, methodological approaches, and operational challenges within humanitarian Blockchain implementations.
column7: While Paper A empirically demonstrates the technical feasibility and efficiency gains of integrating Blockchain with mobile money for transparent cash transfers in a Kenyan humanitarian pilot, Paper B critically ethnographs a Jordanian refugee aid blockchain pilot to reveal how such innovations often function as organizational spectacles driven by strategic ignorance and power asymmetries rather than delivering substantive benefits to beneficiaries.
column8: Both Paper A and Paper B examine Blockchain implementation in humanitarian cash transfer programs but differ analytically as Paper A employs a mixed-methods pilot evaluation focusing on technological integration and operational efficiency in Kenya’s open-loop system, while Paper B uses a qualitative grounded theory case study of the UNWFP’s Ethereum-based project in Jordan to explore socio-political challenges, ethical concerns, and organizational impacts, thereby complementing each other by addressing both technical feasibility and socio-ethical complexities within the humanitarian sector.

column1: Making Sense of Blockchain Technology in the Humanitarian Sector- A Case Study Analysis of ‘Building Blocks’.pdf
column2: Both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate blockchain applications in humanitarian aid focusing on cash transfer efficiency and transparency, but while Paper A offers a qualitative socio-technical case study of a large-scale, private permissioned blockchain system emphasizing governance and ethical implications in refugee camps, Paper B presents a pilot implementation of an open-loop blockchain integrated with mobile money in Kenya that demonstrates practical scalability and operational improvements but with limited exploration of complex digital identity and governance issues.
column4: Both papers explore blockchain applications in humanitarian contexts involving refugees, with Paper A providing an in-depth qualitative case study of a large-scale blockchain project focused on aid distribution and governance in refugee camps, while Paper B offers a systematic scoping review of emerging blockchain uses in migrant and refugee health emphasizing digital identity and health records, thus differing in empirical scope, methodological approach, and sectoral focus but similarly addressing blockchain’s potential and challenges for vulnerable populations.
column5: Both Paper A and Paper B employ qualitative case study methods to analyze blockchain applications in humanitarian and charity sectors respectively, with Paper A focusing on governance and ethical implications of a private permissioned blockchain in refugee aid, while Paper B emphasizes technological innovation and transparency enhancements via a dual blockchain and utility token system during Covid-19 fundraising, thus differing in their sectoral focus, technological complexity, and primary concerns—governance and power dynamics versus operational efficiency and donor trust.
column6: Both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate blockchain applications within the humanitarian sector—Paper A through a qualitative case study of the WFP’s biometric-enabled aid distribution system focusing on governance and power dynamics in refugee aid, and Paper B via a multi-method study of a UK humanitarian supply chain pilot emphasizing drivers, barriers, and trust in blockchain-enabled logistics—differing in their sectoral focus, methodological breadth, and analytical emphasis on socio-technical institutional transformation versus operational supply chain transparency and stakeholder engagement.
column7: Both papers empirically investigate blockchain applications in refugee humanitarian aid through qualitative case studies but differ analytically as Paper A offers a socio-technical governance perspective emphasizing institutional power shifts and ethical concerns in a large-scale project, whereas Paper B employs ethnographic methods to reveal how blockchain pilots function as market spectacles sustained by strategic ignorance that marginalizes refugees and local workers, thus critically challenging the purported benefits and novelty of blockchain innovation in the sector.
column8: Both papers conduct qualitative case studies of the World Food Programme’s Building Blocks blockchain project in humanitarian aid, with Paper B offering an earlier, exploratory grounded theory approach based on limited primary interviews highlighting preliminary social and technical challenges, while Paper A provides a later, more comprehensive socio-technical analysis using secondary data that deepens the understanding of governance, power dynamics, and ethical implications beyond initial operational findings.

column1: Blockchain technology in migrant and refugee health - A scoping review.pdf
column2: Paper A and Paper B both explore Blockchain applications in humanitarian contexts but differ in focus and methodology, with Paper A providing a systematic scoping review of Blockchain’s potential for digital identity and health record management in migrant and refugee health, while Paper B presents an empirical pilot project demonstrating Blockchain’s practical integration with mobile money to enhance transparency and efficiency in cash transfer programming within the Kenyan humanitarian sector.
column3: Both papers investigate blockchain applications in humanitarian contexts involving refugees, with Paper A providing a broad scoping review of diverse digital identity and health record use cases across multiple studies, while Paper B offers an in-depth qualitative case study of a single large-scale blockchain aid project emphasizing governance, power dynamics, and ethical implications beyond technical efficiency.
column5: While both papers explore Blockchain applications to enhance transparency and trust in socially impactful sectors, Paper A employs a systematic scoping review to map emerging uses of Blockchain for digital identity and health record management in migrant and refugee health, whereas Paper B presents an in-depth qualitative case study of a Blockchain-based social marketplace innovating charity fundraising and accountability during Covid-19, highlighting distinct sectors, methodologies, and practical implementations.
column6: Paper A and Paper B both empirically investigate blockchain applications within the humanitarian sector but differ in focus and methodology, with Paper A conducting a scoping literature review on blockchain’s role in migrant and refugee health data management, emphasizing digital identity and health records, while Paper B presents a multi-method qualitative case study on blockchain’s impact on transparency and trust in humanitarian supply chains, offering novel real-world evidence of operational drivers and barriers.
column7: While Paper A provides a systematic scoping review highlighting the emerging technical potential and practical applications of blockchain for improving migrant and refugee health data management, Paper B offers an ethnographic, critical examination of a specific blockchain pilot in refugee aid that reveals how socio-technical dynamics, power asymmetries, and strategic ignorance can undermine the technology’s purported benefits, thus contrasting a technology-optimistic synthesis with a grounded, skeptical case study of blockchain implementation in humanitarian contexts.
column8: Paper A provides a broad scoping review of Blockchain applications in migrant and refugee health emphasizing digital identity and health records, while Paper B offers an in-depth qualitative case study of a specific Blockchain pilot in humanitarian aid focusing on operational, ethical, and socio-political challenges, thus together they complement each other by addressing both the general landscape and detailed implementation dynamics of Blockchain in vulnerable populations within the humanitarian sector.

column1: Managing charity 4.0 with Blockchain- a case study at the time of Covid-19.pdf
column2: Both papers empirically investigate Blockchain applications to enhance transparency and efficiency in social sectors—Paper A through a qualitative case study of an Italian charity platform integrating dual Blockchains and utility tokens during Covid-19, and Paper B via a pilot project deploying an open-loop Blockchain cash transfer system integrated with mobile money in Kenyan humanitarian aid—differing primarily in sector focus, scale, methodological approach, and technological integration, with Paper A emphasizing digital fundraising innovation and Paper B demonstrating operational improvements in cash disbursement within a resource-constrained environment.
column3: Both papers employ qualitative case study methods to analyze blockchain applications in socially impactful sectors—Paper A focusing on enhancing transparency and efficiency in charity fundraising during Covid-19 through a multi-feature public blockchain platform, and Paper B examining governance, power dynamics, and ethical concerns in humanitarian aid distribution via a private permissioned blockchain—thereby differing in sectoral focus, blockchain architecture, and analytical emphasis on technical innovation versus socio-political implications.
column4: Paper A and Paper B both explore Blockchain technology's potential to enhance transparency and data management in socially impactful sectors—charity and migrant/refugee health respectively—yet differ methodologically, with Paper A presenting a qualitative single-case empirical study focused on a novel Blockchain-enabled charity platform during Covid-19, while Paper B offers a systematic scoping review synthesizing limited empirical evidence on Blockchain applications for digital identity and health records in vulnerable populations, highlighting distinct sectoral challenges and implementation considerations.
column6: Both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate Blockchain applications to enhance transparency and trust within socially driven sectors—charity fundraising and humanitarian supply chains respectively—yet differ in scope and methodology, with Paper A offering a single-case qualitative study of an Italian charity platform during Covid-19 emphasizing technological innovation and donor engagement, while Paper B employs a multi-method approach combining focus groups and interviews within a UK humanitarian pilot project to identify adoption drivers and barriers, thereby contributing complementary insights on Blockchain’s practical impacts and challenges in distinct non-profit contexts.
column7: While both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate Blockchain applications in socially-oriented sectors using qualitative case studies, Paper A focuses on the technical innovation and practical benefits of Blockchain for transparency and efficiency in the non-profit charity sector during Covid-19, whereas Paper B critically examines the socio-technical dynamics, power relations, and performative ignorance surrounding a Blockchain pilot in humanitarian refugee aid, highlighting its limitations and symbolic rather than substantive impact.
column8: Both Paper A and Paper B employ qualitative case study methods to examine Blockchain applications in socially impactful sectors—charity fundraising during Covid-19 and humanitarian aid in refugee camps respectively—yet they differ in focus, with Paper A emphasizing technological innovation and operational efficiency in a startup-driven non-profit context, while Paper B highlights socio-political challenges, ethical concerns, and infrastructural limitations in a large-scale international aid pilot, thereby offering complementary insights into Blockchain’s potential and constraints across distinct domains.

column1: Exploring the application of blockchain to humanitarian supply chains- insights from Humanitarian Supply Blockchain pilot project.pdf
column2: Both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate the application of blockchain technology in the humanitarian sector but differ in focus—Paper A qualitatively explores blockchain’s impact on transparency and trust within humanitarian supply chains through a multi-method case study in the UK, while Paper B quantitatively evaluates a large-scale pilot integrating blockchain with mobile money to enhance transparency, accountability, and efficiency in humanitarian cash transfer programming in Kenya—thus collectively advancing practical insights on blockchain’s sector-specific implementations, challenges, and scalability in distinct humanitarian operational domains.
column3: Both papers empirically examine blockchain applications in the humanitarian sector through qualitative case studies—Paper A focusing on supply chain transparency and trust in a UK pilot project using multi-method data collection, while Paper B analyzes the large-scale WFP 'Building Blocks' project emphasizing socio-technical governance, power dynamics, and ethical implications—thereby differing in thematic scope, methodological depth, and novelty with Paper A addressing operational drivers and barriers in supply chains and Paper B providing a critical institutional analysis of blockchain’s transformative potential and risks in humanitarian aid distribution.
column4: While both Paper A and Paper B investigate blockchain applications within humanitarian contexts, Paper A empirically examines blockchain’s impact on transparency and trust in humanitarian supply chains through qualitative case study and focus groups in the UK, whereas Paper B conducts a systematic scoping review of limited empirical and conceptual literature on blockchain’s emerging role in migrant and refugee health data management, highlighting distinct sectors, methods, and stages of technological adoption.
column5: Both Paper A and Paper B empirically examine Blockchain applications aimed at enhancing transparency and trust within socially-driven sectors—humanitarian supply chains and the charity sector respectively—yet differ in their methodological scope, with Paper A employing a multi-method qualitative approach focused on organizational actors in a UK pilot project, while Paper B presents a single-case qualitative analysis of an Italian Blockchain-based social marketplace during Covid-19, highlighting distinct technological innovations and contextual challenges specific to their sectors.
column7: While both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate blockchain pilots in humanitarian contexts using qualitative methods, Paper A adopts a multi-method focus on technical drivers, barriers, and trust enhancement in humanitarian supply chains with a pragmatic lens, whereas Paper B employs ethnographic methods to critically analyze the socio-political dynamics, power asymmetries, and strategic ignorance underlying blockchain adoption in refugee aid, thus contrasting a technology-optimistic perspective with a skeptical, socio-technical critique.
column8: Both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate blockchain applications in humanitarian contexts using qualitative case studies, but while Paper A focuses on multi-method analysis of blockchain’s impact on transparency and trust in humanitarian supply chains within the UK, Paper B employs a grounded theory approach to explore socio-technical, ethical, and operational challenges of blockchain-enabled aid distribution in a refugee camp in Jordan, highlighting differing sectoral emphases, methodological depth, and contextual nuances.

column1: Conjuring a Blockchain Pilot  Ignorance and Innovation in Humanitarian Aid.pdf
column2: Paper A and Paper B both investigate blockchain pilots in humanitarian aid focused on cash assistance, but while Paper A employs ethnographic methods to critically analyze the socio-technical dynamics, power relations, and performative ignorance surrounding a blockchain project in Jordan’s refugee camps, revealing its limited practical benefits and emphasis on organizational spectacle, Paper B presents a technical pilot in Kenya demonstrating blockchain’s operational feasibility and improvements in transparency and efficiency in cash transfers through integration with mobile money, thus differing in methodological approach, conceptual framing, and emphasis on novelty and outcomes within the humanitarian sector.
column3: Both papers critically examine blockchain applications in humanitarian refugee aid through qualitative case studies—Paper A using ethnographic methods to reveal how blockchain pilots like Cash4Work function as strategic spectacles that obscure power asymmetries and marginalize refugees, while Paper B analyzes the large-scale WFP 'Building Blocks' project via secondary data to highlight blockchain’s institutional role in reshaping governance, emphasizing efficiency gains alongside ethical and power centralization concerns—thereby complementing each other by combining micro-level socio-technical ethnography with macro-level governance analysis to provide nuanced insights into blockchain’s socio-political impacts in humanitarian contexts.
column4: Paper A provides an in-depth ethnographic case study critically examining the socio-technical and power dynamics of a blockchain pilot in refugee aid with a focus on innovation spectacle and ignorance, while Paper B offers a systematic scoping review synthesizing emerging blockchain applications in migrant and refugee health, emphasizing digital identity and health records management, thus differing in empirical approach, thematic specificity, and analytical depth but both addressing blockchain’s role in humanitarian contexts involving refugees.
column5: Both papers empirically examine Blockchain applications in the non-profit sector using qualitative case studies but differ analytically as Paper A employs ethnographic methods to critically reveal how blockchain pilots in humanitarian refugee aid function as strategic spectacles reinforcing power asymmetries and ignorance, whereas Paper B offers a descriptive benchmark analysis of a Blockchain-based charity platform during Covid-19 emphasizing technological innovation for transparency and efficiency without critically interrogating socio-political dynamics.
column6: Both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate blockchain pilot projects within the humanitarian sector using qualitative methods, but while Paper A employs ethnographic fieldwork to critically analyze the socio-technical power dynamics and performative ignorance surrounding blockchain adoption in refugee aid in Jordan, Paper B uses focus groups and interviews to assess practical drivers, barriers, and trust-related impacts of blockchain in humanitarian supply chains in the UK, thus differing in thematic focus, methodological depth, and critical framing despite their shared sectoral context.
column8: Both papers empirically investigate blockchain implementation in humanitarian refugee aid through qualitative case studies in Jordan, yet Paper A offers a more ethnographically rich, critical analysis emphasizing the socio-political dynamics and strategic ignorance underpinning blockchain pilots, while Paper B, as a preliminary study using grounded theory, focuses on the technological benefits, operational challenges, and ethical concerns of the UNWFP’s blockchain project, reflecting differing methodological depth, theoretical framing, and stages of research within the same sector.

column1: Blockchain-enabled humanitarian aid- A case study of the World Food Programme.pdf
column2: Both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate Blockchain applications in humanitarian aid to enhance transparency and efficiency—Paper A through a qualitative case study of biometric-enabled aid distribution in a refugee camp using Ethereum, highlighting socio-political and ethical challenges, while Paper B reports a large-scale pilot integrating Blockchain with mobile money for cash transfers in Kenya, emphasizing scalability, technological integration, and operational lessons—thus differing in methodological depth, technological focus, and contextual scale but similarly advancing practical insights on Blockchain’s transformative potential and limitations in humanitarian sectors.
column3: Both papers analyze the World Food Programme’s Building Blocks blockchain project in humanitarian aid using qualitative case study methods, with Paper A emphasizing grounded theory from primary interviews to explore operational, ethical, and infrastructural challenges, while Paper B adopts a socio-technical lens relying on secondary data to highlight governance, power dynamics, and institutional implications, thus differing in data sources, analytical focus, and conceptual framing despite overlapping topics and sector.
column4: Paper A provides an in-depth qualitative case study of Blockchain implementation in humanitarian aid focusing on digital identity and aid distribution in a refugee camp, while Paper B offers a broader scoping review of Blockchain applications in migrant and refugee health, synthesizing secondary literature on digital identity and health records management, thus complementing Paper A’s empirical insights with a wider thematic and sectoral overview but differing in methods, scope, and specific sectoral focus.
column5: Both papers employ qualitative case study methods to explore innovative Blockchain applications aimed at enhancing transparency and efficiency in aid-related sectors—Paper A focusing on biometric-enabled Blockchain for humanitarian food aid distribution in refugee camps, highlighting socio-political and ethical challenges, while Paper B examines a multi-feature Blockchain social marketplace improving charity fundraising and donor trust during Covid-19, emphasizing technological integration and pandemic-driven operational adaptations.
column6: Both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate blockchain implementation in humanitarian contexts using qualitative case studies, with Paper A focusing on biometric-enabled aid distribution in refugee camps and exploring socio-political and ethical implications, while Paper B examines blockchain’s impact on transparency and trust in humanitarian supply chains through a multi-method approach, highlighting operational drivers and barriers, thereby differing in sectoral focus, methodological breadth, and thematic emphasis on social versus supply chain governance challenges.
column7: While both Paper A and Paper B empirically investigate blockchain pilots in Jordanian refugee aid contexts using qualitative methods, Paper A adopts a grounded theory case study to highlight technological benefits and operational challenges of blockchain implementation by the UNWFP, whereas Paper B employs ethnographic methods to critically expose the socio-political dynamics and strategic ignorance underpinning blockchain adoption as a reputational spectacle that marginalizes refugees and local aid workers, thus differing markedly in analytical focus, conceptual novelty, and interpretive framing despite overlapping sectors and topics.
